Empires & Puzzles Helgi Costume Review: The Dwarven Replenisher

Helgi's costume turns the rage dial down and the efficiency dial up. With massive boosted health passives and increased damage on his 8-hit special, is this the ultimate 3-star tank for the burn meta? We investigate the Dwarven Replenisher.
Helgi Costume Review: Bigger Heals, Harder Hits, Same Small Dwarf
Helgi Costume: The Dwarven Replenisher Takes Charge
transforms the Dwarven Rage Runner into the "Dwarven Replenisher." Released in the

portal, this costume takes everything good about the base version—the random hits, the buff reset—and injects it with better stats and significantly stronger passives. As a Rare (3-star) Fire Paladin, he competes in a crowded field but distinguishes himself with a passive ability that makes him an absolute nightmare for Burn-based teams. If the base version is a shotgun, the costume is an automatic shotgun with a self-cleaning mechanism.

In his costume, Helgi swaps the aggressive reds for a more composed, perhaps "replenished" look. He still retains the heavy dwarven armor and the impressive facial hair, but there is a sense of refinement here. The visual shift suggests a dwarf who has mastered his rage and is now channeling it into pure efficiency. The "Replenisher" title fits the blue/teal accents in his gear, hinting at the massive health boosts he provides to himself.
The costume provides a significant stat overhaul.
579 (Base) - A noticeable bump over the original's 545.
When fully maxed and Limit Broken (LB2), his stats are formidable for a 3-star:

~966
These stats put him well within the upper echelon of modern 3-star heroes, allowing him to tank effectively in 3-star tournaments or survive as a flank.
"Dwarven Recharge" is a direct upgrade to the base skill.
(up from 130%). This 20% increase might seem small, but multiplied by 8 hits, that is an extra
Resets the duration of buffs for all allies.
This remains a top-tier utility effect. Keeping a Defense Up or Attack Up buff active for the entire match can easily be the deciding factor in a war of attrition.
. This is one of the highest total damage percentages available on a 3-star card.
per burn resist. This is the standout number. 600 HP is often 50-60% of a 3-star hero's total health pool.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
This is where the Costume truly shines over the base version.
The Nidavellir family bonus ensures that his Molten Core is charging up as he takes damage, prepping a nasty surprise for when he casts.
This is the game-changer. The base version gives 450 HP and 5% mana. The costume gives
. If an enemy Toon Jahangir or Azlar hits him, Helgi gains a massive chunk of health and a significant mana boost. It effectively turns the enemy's offense into his battery.
The corrosive burn is slightly stronger (170 damage vs 147) and the defense down is slightly steeper (-13% vs -12%).
gives him a mana generation bump at the start of the battle. For a Slow hero, this is arguably better than the Base version's Attack Up, as it helps him fire that first devastating volley sooner.

3-star tournaments have long been dominated by specific metas (Treevil, then Toons). Helgi Costume enters as a disruptive force, specifically designed to counter the heavy burn meta prevalent in red-heavy tournaments or against specific event bosses.
With 1200% total damage potential and nearly 1000 HP at LB2, he is at the cutting edge of 3-star power creep. He leaves older Season 1 and 2 heroes in the dust.
for 3-star Rush tournaments. Outside of Rush, he is a niche counter-pick against burn teams, but within that niche, he is arguably the best in his rarity.
Higher base stats across the board.
The standard bonus applies, giving stat increases that make the base version irrelevant unless you specifically need the different Aether Power or look.
Wear the costume. There is almost no scenario where the base version is superior.
Maximizes survivability. With the Paladin talent and his high defense, he becomes very hard to kill, allowing him to abuse his burn-resist passive more often.
Pushes his attack stat to maximize the 1200% damage potential.
Makes him squishier, risking death before firing.
. His passive healing is static (600 HP), so having high defense makes that health worth more effective HP. You want him alive to reset buffs and absorb burns.
600 Boosted Health makes him arguably the best anti-burn 3-star in the game.
Resetting buffs is a timelessly good ability.
You cannot control who he hits, which can be frustrating when trying to snipe a specific threat.
Hitting a Boril or Cyprian 8 times is a quick way to commit suicide.
work in Bloody Battle (healing is disabled). However, if the game codes it as a "gain" rather than a "heal" (like minions), it might work, but usually, it doesn't.
Boosted Health is blocked in Bloody Battle. His value drops there.
Helgi C - Treevil - Faiez. A classic "make the opponent cry" Rush defense. Faiez blocks ailments, Treevil breaks stats, Helgi resets Faiez's block duration.
Use him against red tanks in tournaments. Even if the tiles are bad, if they burn him, he heals.
If the enemy has no burn, his best passive does nothing.
While he resets buffs, he doesn't cleanse ailments (unless he resists burn). A heavy poison/water damage team can wear him down.
This is a fantastic pull. Even as a slow hero, the sheer damage output will help you clear map stages and quests easily. The passive healing makes him very forgiving to play with.

Limit Break him immediately for your Rush Defense and Offense. The 600 HP heal is absurd and can single-handedly win matches against Toon Jahangir or similar heroes. He replaces older slow hitters like Sudri in specific matchups where sustainability is keyed to resisting ailments.
Players immediately noticed the upgrade: "600 boosted health and 10% Mana... that is naturally strong."
The comparison to the base version was stark: "Costume is better... simple comparisons show it."
The synergy with other Untold Tales heroes and the sheer stat stick nature of the costume was a highlight in discussions.
"Buff reset is his strength, high damage is a nice bonus," remains the core sentiment, but the costume makes that "bonus" much scarier.

Helgi Costume is the definition of a modern 3-star hero. He takes a classic archetype (the slow nuker) and layers on complex, high-value passives that interact with the meta. He doesn't just hit hard; he punishes the enemy for trying to play their game (using burns). He is a stout, fiery brick wall that resets your buffs and replenishes his own health bar. If you see him in a Rush tournament, bring a dispeller, and for the love of Odin, do not bring a flamethrower.
Review of the Helgi Costume (C1), a 3-star Fire Paladin from Untold Tales 2. We analyze his upgraded stats, improved burn resistance, and why he is a top-tier pick for Rush Attack tournaments.
